intro: Quercus cerris var. aegilops, commonly known as the Turkish oak, is a variant of the Persian oak. It is a deciduous tree native to the eastern Mediterranean region, including parts of Turkey and southern Europe. The tree is characterized by its large, lobed leaves and acorns that are often enclosed in a cupule. It typically grows to a height of 20–30 meters and has a broad, spreading crown. The bark is thick and fissured, providing a rugged appearance.
